The idea would be to abandon the confrontational approach and embark on a methodical reconstruction of the relationship with the European Union. The right approach is to deploy a gradual strategy. At first, it would involve restoring trust through targeted cooperation on security, research, and youth mobility. Once this solid foundation is established, the priority would be to lift the most burdensome trade barriers by negotiating mutual recognition agreements for standards and a comprehensive veterinary agreement. The ultimate objective of this approach is to rejoin the single market. Thus, this would make it possible to restore economic prosperity by streamlining exchanges, to strengthen national security through increased cooperation, and to reopen concrete opportunities for citizens, marking a deep economic reintegration within Europe.

The idea would be to end post-Brexit isolation by initiating a gradual and complete reintegration into the European Union. The right approach is to reverse the most damaging consequences of the exit by rejoining, as a first step, the Customs Union. To achieve this, the priority would be to promptly restore the free movement of people, offering reciprocal rights to live, work and study across Europe, and to reinstate the Erasmus programme. Any new trade agreement would be conditioned on compliance with the highest social and environmental standards. Thus, this would pave the way, as soon as political conditions allow, to full and complete accession to the European Union, regarded as the only solution to guarantee long-term prosperity and security.

The idea would be to finalize the break with the European Union by restoring total economic and legal sovereignty, deemed indispensable to unlock national potential. The priority would be to unilaterally repeal with immediate effect the thousands of European regulations still in force, then to initiate a renegotiation of the trade agreement to remove the alignment clauses that constrain competitiveness. Particular attention would be paid to the full reintegration of Northern Ireland into the national internal market, abandoning the current framework that keeps it under European commercial jurisdiction. Thus, this would make it possible to establish a new relationship of simple cooperation between sovereign neighbors, restoring the primacy of national law and creating the conditions for a deliberately assumed regulatory divergence to stimulate the economy.

The idea would be to stabilize the relationship with our European neighbours on a pragmatic and sovereign basis. The approach consists in respecting the existing commercial and cooperation framework, including the provisions relating to Northern Ireland, to ensure the predictability of exchanges. Cooperation would be engaged constructively on dossiers of mutual interest such as science, defence and economic development, without, however, aiming for a realignment or new mobility agreements. The priority remains full regulatory autonomy and control of national borders. Thus, this would allow maintaining a functional good-neighbour relationship focused on concrete benefits, without compromising the independence of the country's trade and migration policy.

The idea would be to build an entirely sovereign commercial and international policy, turning the page on post-Brexit arrangements to redefine relations on the basis of national interests. The right approach is to stop prioritizing the relationship with the European Union and to turn resolutely toward the emerging powers (BRICS) and build a new network of partnerships. Any future trade agreement will be founded on principles of fair exchange and non-exploitation, in rupture with traditional free trade treaties. The definition of industrial standards and mobility rules will fall exclusively within national competence to serve the objectives of reindustrialization and control of flows. Thus, this would allow the country to pursue a truly independent foreign and commercial policy, freed from traditional power blocs and capable of defending its economic and social interests on the world stage.

question: What are the defense and security priorities (level of spending, industry, alliances)?

propositions.value: The idea would be to restore a credible and sovereign defense posture, based on clear commitments and modernized capabilities. The priority is to guarantee the fundamentals: an absolute commitment to the Atlantic alliance and nuclear deterrence. A strategic review launched from the first year will define the needs, with a view to establishing a trajectory of military spending reaching 2,5 % of GDP. At the same time, a defense industrial strategy will be deployed to support national companies, secure supply chains and better assist veterans. Thus, this would strengthen the country's influence within strategic alliances, guarantee its security in the face of emerging threats and align defense imperatives with economic policy.

The idea would be to guarantee national security and to project a stabilizing influence in an increasingly hostile international context, based on credible deterrence. To achieve this, the commitment is to raise defense spending to a new floor of 2.5% of GDP by 2030, a standard that should be promoted to all allies. This increase will fund the modernization of the forces and a revitalization of the national defense industry, supported by at least 10 billion pounds of investment in ammunition production. Collective security will be strengthened by guaranteed long-term military and financial support to Ukraine and by deepening strategic alliances. Thus, this would enable the armed forces to be equipped with the necessary capabilities to face future threats, to cement the country's leadership within key alliances, and to protect national interests sustainably.

The idea would be to reposition the country's defense posture as a pillar of European security, in response to geopolitical uncertainty and to ensure increased strategic autonomy. The right approach would be to increase defense spending to at least 2.5% of GDP and to reverse the reduction in the armed forces' personnel. This ambition would be backed by an integrated defense industrial policy to streamline acquisitions and by renewed leadership within European alliances, complementary to OTAN. In this way, it would make it possible to guarantee national security by credible means, to modernize the armed forces while ensuring the proper use of public funds, and to strengthen the country's role as a reliable partner and a pillar of European security.

The idea would be to redefine national security by abandoning nuclear deterrence in favor of conventional defense and strengthened diplomacy. The right approach is to undertake a complete unilateral disarmament, canceling the Trident program and signing the ONU treaty banning nuclear weapons. Rather than increasing budgets, this strategy would allow a massive reallocation of military spending. Within alliances such as OTAN, the priority would be to actively promote a purely defensive doctrine, where diplomacy systematically takes precedence over military intervention and which adopts the principle of not resorting first to nuclear weapons. Thus, this would allow national security to be founded on cooperation and international law, while freeing considerable resources to address the real climate and social emergencies.

The idea would be to restore the country's full military sovereignty by undertaking a significant rearmament and ensuring that the armed forces have the necessary means to defend the nation. The proper approach is to undertake a scheduled increase of the defense budget to reach 2,5 % of GDP in three years, then 3 % in six years. This investment would support the recruitment of 30 000 full-time soldiers and the revival of a sovereign defense industrial and technological base, stimulated by tax incentives. The status and remuneration of military personnel would also be revalorized to ensure the attractiveness of careers. Thus, this would make it possible to guarantee a credible defense force, equipped with cutting-edge equipment produced nationally, and to fully ensure the country's security and its influence within its strategic alliances.

The idea would be to rebuild the defense posture around the protection of the national territory and the strengthening of the country's strategic resilience. The central axis would consist of ring-fencing a defense budget at 2,5 % of GDP, a strict floor separate from external aid. In parallel, a complete overhaul of acquisition processes would aim to strengthen the national industrial and technological base. Commitment within historical alliances would be maintained, notably with European and Commonwealth partners, but refocused on collective defense and domestic production rather than external interventions. An independent nuclear deterrent would remain a non-negotiable pillar. Thus, this would guarantee increased strategic autonomy and a credible defense capability, capable of protecting national interests in the face of evolving modern threats.

The idea would be to regain control of defense policy to refocus it on a strictly defensive posture and full national sovereignty, breaking with military alliances perceived as hegemonic and dangerous. The right approach is to submit to the people, by referendum, the question of membership in the dominant military alliance, in order to replace it with mutual security agreements centered on the protection of peoples. The level of spending will be optimized by a complete revision of the military hierarchy, redirecting the savings achieved toward frontline equipment and personnel. A sovereign procurement policy will systematically favor the national industry to guarantee strategic autonomy. Thus, this would make it possible to build a credible, better-equipped and autonomous defense force, while freeing significant resources for national priorities and ensuring true strategic independence.
